Delaware North, the company whose chairman owns the Boston Bruins, is buying a piece of an eSports team. 
The investment, announced Thursday morning, is just the latest in a trend of traditional sports teams investing in professional video gaming. The NBA announced its NBA 2K eLeague partnership earlier Thursday, a joint venture in which all 30 NBA organizations could eventually have e-Teams of their own. 
Delaware North, which owns and operates TD Garden, where the Bruins play, announced a strategic partnership with Splyce, an eSports team that has teams and players around the world who compete in such video games as League of Legends, Call of Duty and World of Warcraft. 
Jeremy Jacobs, who owns the Bruins, is chairman of Delaware North, a Buffalo-based hospitality and food services company with annual revenue of about $3 billion. The company commissioned reports called The Future of Sports — one was released in 2015 and another in 2016 — that predicted robust growth in eSports.
